Triggering Event:
"Jesus fucking Christ! Not another goddamn power cut!" John, a 27-year-old chef, slammed his fist on the countertop of his once vibrant, now desolate apartment. The clock hands mocked him at 1:30 AM; it was too late for sleep and too early for breakfast prep. His phone's flashlight flickered on, casting eerie shadows in the dark room. He stumbled to the fuse box, fingers trembling with anger and exhaustion.

Fucking hell, this is the third time this month! he cursed silently, his mind racing back to a memory of his ex-wife, Sarah, laughing at him for being too paranoid about safety checks. But now, it was just John and his goddamn neurotic tendencies in this empty shell of an apartment.

He yanked open the door to the fuse box, squinting at the mess of wires. His heart pounded in his chest like a fucking drum solo. He'd been neglecting himself, he knew that - late nights at the restaurant, early mornings alone in the cold apartment, no one to share breakfast with anymore.

Sarah had left him for some city banker with a nine-to-five and a manicured lawn. "You're never there," she'd said, her voice echoing in their once-shared bedroom. And now, he was always fucking here, but the goddamn power kept failing him.

John's fingers fumbled over the switches, his mind wandering back to Sarah's laughter, her warm touch, the comforting hum of their shared life. His throat tightened, and he felt that familiar sting behind his eyes - tears threatening to spill over like a fucking leaky faucet.

Suddenly, there was a spark, followed by a loud pop. The fuse box exploded in a cloud of smoke. John stumbled back, coughing, his heart pounding wildly. "Fuck!" he yelled into the darkness, his voice echoing through the empty apartment. He was alone, again, with only his anger and neglect for company.
Generated Assessment:
Another power outage, and I'm starting to think it's because I'm just not good enough. I mean, what's wrong with me? Can't even keep the lights on. It's not like I'm asking for much. Just a simple, reliable power source so I can cook my food and get some rest.

It's not like I've been working non-stop at the restaurant, pouring my heart out every night, only to come home to this...this...empty shell of an apartment. No one to share it with, no one to care. Maybe if I was more like those city bankers, all successful and put together, they wouldn't leave me for someone else.

But no, I'm stuck here, alone, with nothing but my thoughts to keep me company. And these thoughts are telling me that I'm not good enough. That I'm just not worthy of love or respect. It's like I'm living in a nightmare, and I don't know how to wake up.

I try to shake off the feeling, tell myself it's just a coincidence. But deep down, I know it's not. This power outage is just another reminder of my failures. My neglect. My inability to provide for anyone but myself.

And now, as I stand here in the darkness, waiting for the fire department to arrive, I can feel my frustration boiling over. Why does this have to happen to me? Why can't I just have one thing go right for once?

As I wait, I start to wonder if maybe I am the problem. If maybe I'm just not cut out for this whole adult thing. Maybe I should just give up, throw in the towel, and admit defeat. After all, what's the point of trying when everything seems to be going wrong anyway?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Granny's got her pearls on again today, that fancy new set from the jewelry store downtown. I seen 'em in the display case last week when I was there for coffee with the chief. She'd been cooing over them like they were the eighth wonder of the world. Must've popped right out and bought 'em soon as my back was turned.

I watched her, all dolled up, walking down the street arm in arm with that no-good husband of hers, Bob. He's always been a flashy one, but now he's got himself a new toy to show off too - some shiny sports car parked out front of their house every morning. I swear it's like they're trying to rub it in my face.

I remember when we started on the force together, back in '75. We were both just kids, eager and green. We'd share war stories over beers after our shifts, laugh till our sides hurt. But that was before life got in the way, before she got her claws into him.

Now here they are, strolling down Main like they own the place. She's got her new pearls around her neck, and he's wearing a grin wider than the Grand Canyon. I can feel it rising up inside me, hot and bitter. Envy's a nasty beast, always has been. It's gnawing at my insides, making my hands shake on the steering wheel.

I pull over, watching them through the windshield as they head into that fancy new café. The one she made such a fuss about when it opened last month. I can hear her now, "Oh, Martha, you simply must try their lattes! They're to die for!"

I take a deep breath, trying to push down the green monster inside me. But it's no use. It's still there, clawing at my throat like a wild animal. I can feel tears pricking at the corners of my eyes, and not just because of the smoke from that damn car backfiring down the street.

I sit here for a while longer, watching them through the window as they laugh and chat with the other patrons. They look so happy, so carefree. And here I am, stuck in my old cruiser, alone except for this ugly feeling churning in my gut.

It's not fair, I think to myself. She didn't even want him at first. But now...now she's got everything. The husband, the house, the fancy cars, and those goddamn pearls. And what do I have? A cold bed, an empty house, and a heart full of envy.

I wipe away a tear, take one last look at them through the window, then put my car in gear and drive off into the setting sun.
Generated Assessment:
As I watch Granny stroll down Main Street, her new pearls glinting in the sunlight, I'm reminded of the countless times she's gotten ahead. Always had a knack for snagging the best things in life. I swear, she's got a magnetic field that draws success and happiness towards her. Meanwhile, I'm stuck in neutral, going nowhere fast.

Her husband, Bob, may seem like a flashy distraction, but let's be real – he's just a prop in her game of life. She's the one who really pulls the strings. I mean, have you seen the way she carries herself? Confident, poised, and always in control. Me? I'm just along for the ride, trying to keep up with her pace.

We used to be friends, back in the day. Shared laughs and war stories over beers. But that was before she became the high-achieving machine she is today. Now, she's just a reminder of everything I'll never have. Those pearls, that fancy car, that perfect marriage – it's all just a cruel joke, a constant reminder of my own mediocrity.

I glance over at the café where she's meeting friends. She's laughing and chatting, clearly the center of attention. I'm just sitting here, alone, wondering why I ever thought I could measure up. Maybe I should just stick to my old routine – coffee with the chief, maybe a quick nap before dinner. That sounds like a much safer bet than trying to keep up with Granny's whirlwind lifestyle.

As I drive away, I catch a glimpse of myself in the rearview mirror. My hair's a mess, my clothes are worn, and my expression looks like I've lost my last friend. Yeah, that's me – the perpetual also-ran, forever stuck in the shadows of someone else's greatness.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quietude of his empty classroom, John found himself staring at the blank chalkboard, its pristine surface mocking him like an old friend he barely recognized. The school day had ended hours ago, but he couldn't bring himself to leave, not when every corner whispered echoes of her laughter.

His wife, Emily, had been gone for three months now, and each day felt like a battle against the suffocating silence she'd left behind. He'd tried to fill their home with noise - music, TV, even talking to himself, but it was never enough. It was always just him, shouting into the void.

Today, he found a note tucked into his desk drawer at school. Emily's handwriting danced across the paper, playful and carefree. "I love you," it said, "even when you're grading papers." He could almost hear her voice, see her smile, and for a moment, it was like she was there with him.

But then reality crashed in like a wave, cold and unforgiving. The note crumpled in his fist as tears stung his eyes. He wanted to scream, to rage at the unfairness of it all, but he just sat there, slumped over her words, sobbing silently into the empty classroom.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm so sick of these stupid schools. Every teacher I've ever met has been a total disaster. They don't know how to teach, they're always late, and they make us do pointless homework. I swear, if one more teacher tries to make me grade papers, I'll lose my mind.

It's not like I'm asking for much. Just give me some decent instruction and let me get out of here. But no, instead I get stuck with clueless teachers who can't even be bothered to write a decent note. Like, what's the point of even having a note? It's just going to sit there, reminding me of everything I've lost.

My wife left me three months ago, and it feels like the whole world has turned against me. Every day is just a struggle to keep myself sane. And now this...this fake note from some teacher who thinks they can just waltz in and pretend like everything is okay. Newsflash: it's not okay. Nothing is okay.

I'm done with this place. I'm done with teaching, done with education, done with life itself. If I have to sit through one more boring lecture or deal with one more incompetent teacher, I'll snap. And it won't be pretty.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Old George, a nurse of nearly five decades, was cleaning out his late wife Martha's knitting corner. He'd been putting it off for months now, but today felt right. As he dusted off her favorite scarlet yarn, he found something tucked beneath it - an unopened letter addressed to him in Martha's neat, looping handwriting.

He sat down on the worn-out rocking chair, his heart pounding softly like a distant drumbeat. He could almost feel Martha beside him, her gentle hands guiding his as they'd once opened Christmas presents together. But not this time. This was hers alone to send even after she was gone.

With trembling fingers, George carefully tore open the envelope and unfolded the crisp paper inside. It was a letter written in blue ink, the same shade Martha used for her daily journals that now sat gathering dust on their shared bookshelf.

"Dearest George," it began, and his eyes welled up with tears. He knew what this was - a final goodbye from his beloved wife who had slipped away quietly one chill winter morning.

He read on, her words filling the empty room with memories:

*Remember our walks by the lake when autumn leaves crunched underfoot? I want you to keep walking, George. Don't stop because I'm not there. Life goes on.*

A lump formed in his throat as he reached the last line:

*And please, don't feel guilty about that argument we had before my diagnosis. It was nothing more than a fleeting storm between two people who loved each other deeply.*

George felt a pang of guilt pierce through him like a knife twisting slowly. He'd forgotten about that argument, buried it deep under layers of grief and denial. Now, Martha's words brought it all rushing back - their raised voices, her tear-streaked face, his stubborn refusal to apologize...

He folded the letter carefully and placed it back inside its envelope. As he stood up, he made a silent promise to himself and to Martha: He would walk again by the lake, let autumn leaves crunch underfoot once more. And maybe, just maybe, he'd find forgiveness too - for both of them.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why did it have to take me so long to sort through Martha's stuff? I swear, it feels like the whole world is conspiring against me. Every time I think I've finally gotten caught up, some new mess pops up. Like, what's the point of even trying?

I found this stupid letter in her old yarn stash. Unopened, just sitting there waiting for me. Great, just great. Now I'll never know what she really wanted to say. Probably something terrible anyway. She always was one for dramatics.

I mean, come on, "remember our walks by the lake"? Please. That's just code for "you're going to lose me". And don't even get me started on that argument we had before she got sick. I knew it was a big deal at the time, but now...now it just feels like a pointless waste of breath. We were both just so angry, and now she's gone. What's the difference?

I'm telling you, life is just one big disappointment after another. First, she gets sick, then she dies, and now I'm stuck dealing with all this sentimental crap. Can't anyone just leave me alone? I thought we were done with all that emotional baggage.

I guess I'll just put the letter back where I found it. No sense in dwelling on it. Besides, I don't need some ghostly reminder of everything that went wrong. Just leave me be.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Oh, for f*ck's sake! Just when I thought my day couldn't get any worse, I open the fridge to grab my lunch, and what do I find? A goddamn science experiment gone wrong! It was like watching a horror movie in slow motion - mold so thick it looked like someone had thrown up green paint. And the smell... holy sh*t, it was like a thousand rotting socks decided to have a party in there. I mean, seriously? It's been two years since Sarah passed, but does that mean I'm supposed to forget how to use a fridge too? Now I've gotta spend my break cleaning up this putrid mess, all thanks to our lovely 'housekeeper' who seems to think food lasts forever if you just ignore it long enough. F*ck me sideways!"
Generated Assessment: Ugh, every single day feels like a never-ending nightmare after today. The state of our housekeeper's work is always a disaster waiting to happen. I swear, they must think we're made of money or something. Two years since Sarah left us, and yet the fridge still looks like a biohazard lab. It's like they're trying to drive me crazy on purpose. Every time I walk into that kitchen, I feel like I'm stepping into a toxic waste dump. And don't even get me started on the smell – it's like they're intentionally trying to make me gag. I'm starting to think that our housekeeper has no concept of personal space or basic hygiene. It's not just the fridge; it's the whole atmosphere around here that's suffocating me. I'm beginning to wonder if anyone actually cares about maintaining a clean and comfortable living environment anymore. It's like we're stuck in some kind of perpetual hellhole, and I'm the only one who notices.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Every day for the past decade, Edna had been tinkering away at her desk, lines of code dancing across her screen like old friends. She was a software engineer's software engineer, her fingers tapping out algorithms with an ease that belied her 77 years. Her colleagues had long since retired, but not Edna. Not until she'd finished what she'd started.

One evening, as the sun dipped low and the office grew quiet, Edna's phone rang. It was her ex-husband, Harold. They hadn't spoken in years, not since the divorce that had left Edna with a bitter taste in her mouth and a heart full of resentment. She let it ring, watching the screen light up with his name until it finally went silent.

But Harold didn't give up so easily. The next day, he emailed her. Then he called again. And again. Each time, Edna felt that old familiar anger bubbling up inside her. Why was he doing this now? After all these years?

One afternoon, as she sat at her desk, her heart pounding with a resentment that had grown stale but not lessened, Harold walked into the office. He stood there, in his rumpled suit and his apologetic smile, looking exactly like the man who'd broken her heart.

"What are you doing here, Harold?" Edna asked, her voice as cold as she could make it.

"I wanted to see you, Edna," he said, running a hand through his thinning hair. "I've been thinking about us. About what happened."

Edna felt the resentment surge within her like a tidal wave. Here he was, standing before her after all these years, acting like they were still married, still in love. Like he hadn't torn their lives apart.

"You had your chance, Harold," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "You threw it away."

Harold reached out to touch her hand, but Edna snatched it away. She couldn't bear his touch, not now, not ever again.

"I know I did," he said, looking down at the floor. "But I'm sorry, Edna. I'm so sorry."

Edna felt a lump form in her throat. Sorry wasn't enough. It would never be enough to undo the pain he'd caused her. She turned back to her computer, her fingers flying over the keys as she typed out lines of code, each one a testament to her resentment.

"You should go," she said, not looking at him. "You shouldn't have come here."

Harold hesitated for a moment before turning and walking away. As he left, Edna felt the familiar anger wash over her once more. She took a deep breath, letting it out slowly as she turned back to her work. Some things never changed, she thought bitterly. And some things, like her resentment towards Harold, were forever etched in stone.
Generated Assessment:
Are you kidding me? This guy just shows up after all these years, expecting everything to be okay? Newsflash, Harold: it's not okay. You broke my heart, you destroyed our life together, and now you think a simple apology will fix everything?

What, do you think a few empty words are going to erase the memories of how you treated me? How you made me feel like I was nothing? You're just trying to butter me up, to get me to forgive you, but it's too late for that. I'm done with you, Harold. Done.

And another thing, what's with the "I'm sorry" routine? Sorry isn't enough. Sorry doesn't even begin to cover the damage you did. You should be sorry, Harold. You should be sorry every day for the rest of your life.

And don't even get me started on your pathetic attempt to touch me. Are you insane? Do you really think a little pat on the hand is going to make everything okay? No, it's not okay. It's never going to be okay.

Just leave, Harold. Just leave and don't come back. I don't want to see your face around here anymore. I don't want to hear your voice. I just want to be left alone.

You know what? Forget it. Forget we ever met. Forget we ever had anything together. Because if you had any real feelings for me, you wouldn't have messed me up like this. But no, instead you just kept on screwing me over, and now you expect me to just forget and move on? Get out of my sight, Harold. Get out of my life.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In his sterile laboratory, Dr. Henry Thompson meticulously adjusted the microscope's focus, his usually steady hands trembling slightly. The clock on the wall ticked away the interminable seconds, its rhythmic clicking echoing the emptiness within him. He had been at this for hours, days perhaps, lost in the futile search for something—anything—that could reignite the spark of hope he'd once felt.

His assistant, a young woman with fiery hair and even fierier intellect, entered the room softly. "Dr. Thompson," she began tentatively, "it's late. You should go home."

Henry didn't respond, merely adjusted his glasses and leaned closer to the eyepiece. His wife, Emily, had loved this lab, had often teased him about his 'precious specimens'. He could almost hear her laughter now, but it was drowned out by the crushing weight of silence.

The young woman tried again, "Dr. Thompson, you've barely slept or eaten in days. You need to take care of yourself."

Henry felt a surge of annoyance. How dare she presume to tell him how to live? His life had ended with Emily's. He was merely going through the motions now, waiting for time to run out.

As if on cue, his phone rang. He ignored it, letting it go to voicemail. It was probably just another well-meaning friend or colleague checking up on him. They meant well, but they didn't understand. No one did.

The caller left a message. Henry listened to it absently while continuing his work. "Dr. Thompson," the voice said, "this is Dr. Patel from the National Institute of Health. We've received your proposal and would like to discuss it further..."

Henry froze, the words sinking in slowly. His proposal—he'd sent it out weeks ago, a desperate grasp at straws. He had poured all his remaining hope into that document, only to have it rejected by every institution he'd contacted.

He felt a familiar sense of despair begin to rise within him, threatening to consume him whole. What was the point? Why bother trying when nothing ever changed?

His assistant watched him closely, concern etched on her face. "Dr. Thompson?" she asked softly.

Henry looked at her, then at the microscope, and finally at his phone. He felt a strange sensation in his chest—a flicker of something he hadn't felt in years. It was faint, barely there, but it was enough to make him pause.

He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what was to come. "Arrange a meeting with Dr. Patel," he said, his voice hoarse but determined. "It seems we have some work to do."
Generated Assessment:
As I stood before the polished surface of my office mirror, I couldn't help but feel a pang of inadequacy. My colleagues seemed to effortlessly glide through their days, their smiles and laughter a stark contrast to my own stoic demeanor. Their accomplishments, too, were a constant reminder of my own shortcomings.

I recalled the countless meetings where they effortlessly charmed our clients, their words dripping with confidence and authority. Meanwhile, I struggled to find the right words, my mind a jumble of nervous thoughts and self-doubt. Even my own research, once a beacon of passion and purpose, now seemed dull and uninspired compared to theirs.

Their success stories, too, served as a cruel reminder of my own failures. That promotion they received after just two years of service? A travesty, really. I had spent decades honing my craft, pouring over texts and conducting experiments, only to be overlooked for someone so... inexperienced.

But what truly stung was the way they seemed to effortlessly balance work and personal life. While I toiled away in my cramped, cluttered office, they would often stroll out for lunch, laughing and chatting with ease. Their weekends, too, were filled with leisurely activities – hiking, traveling, or simply enjoying quiet evenings at home. Me? I was lucky to get a few hours of sleep before the next day's grueling schedule.

And yet, despite these feelings of inadequacy, I couldn't shake the nagging sense that I was somehow better off. After all, I had dedicated my life to my craft, driven by a fierce passion and unwavering commitment. Perhaps, I thought, it was time to reevaluate my priorities, to refocus on what truly mattered.

With newfound determination, I set to work, pouring over my notes and planning my next move. I would prove them wrong, show them that I, too, could achieve greatness. But as I worked, a small voice in the back of my mind whispered doubts, reminding me that I was, indeed, just a shadow of those more accomplished individuals around me.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quietude of her studio, where the scent of oil paints and turpentine hung heavier than usual today, Mrs. Charlotte Beauchamp was meticulously blending hues on her palette. Her husband, Mr. Henry Beauchamp, a man of considerable charm but negligible artistic acumen, burst in like a clumsy breeze.

"Darling," he announced, flourishing an invitation card as if it were a prize-winning masterpiece, "the gallery has asked for another one of your landscapes! Isn't that marvelous?"

Charlotte, her bitterness towards Henry's relentless optimism as palpable as the fumes from her paints, paused. She looked up at him, one eyebrow arched higher than the Sistine Chapel ceiling.

"Indeed," she drawled, "it is absolutely splendid. After all, who needs a well-rounded portfolio when one can simply regurgitate the same ol' pastoral scenes ad nauseam?"

Henry, oblivious to her tone, beamed even wider. "Exactly, my dear! They love your style!"

Charlotte turned back to her palette, stirring the colors with unnecessary vigor. "Oh, I do hope they'll also appreciate my unique ability to turn anything remotely pleasant into a bitter tableau," she muttered under her breath, ensuring Henry heard not a word of her sarcastic soliloquy.
Generated Assessment: "I am utterly delighted by this development, yet simultaneously appalled by the sheer audacity of the gallery's request. It is either a masterstroke of genius, elevating me to unprecedented heights of artistic recognition, or a catastrophic blunder, reducing my already fragile ego to tatters. There is no middle ground, no room for nuance or subtlety. The gallery's decision is either a testament to my unparalleled talent or a declaration of war against my very existence. I shall neither rejoice nor despair; I shall merely exist, suspended precariously between these two extremes, forever trapped in this abyss of unyielding certainty."<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the chill of the early morning, as Mrs. Harriet Thompson fastened her name tag, she felt the familiar pang of sadness that had become her constant companion. The fluorescent lights of the retail store flickered on, casting a harsh glow over the neatly stacked shelves, each item whispering tales of families and celebrations it would never know.

Harriet's reflection in the glass counter seemed to mock her, the lines around her eyes deepening like canyons carved by endless nights of sleeplessness. She thought back to the laughter that once echoed through their home, the warmth of her late husband's hand holding hers as they walked down these very aisles on their weekly shopping trip.

The bell above the door chimed, jolting Harriet from her reverie. A young couple entered, arms entwined, their eyes sparkling with an intimacy Harriet had long forgotten. They were pushing a cart adorned with a 'Just Married' sign, their laughter filling the air like a melody Harriet couldn't quite remember.

As she rang up their purchases, each item - a set of towels, a new kettle, a plush throw rug - served as a cruel reminder of what she no longer had. The sadness she had been nursing all morning threatened to spill over, but she held it at bay, pasting on the practiced smile she reserved for such occasions.

The young husband looked at her, his eyes soft with pity. "Are you alright, ma'am?" he asked softly. Harriet felt a lump form in her throat, threatening to choke her. She managed a nod, her vision blurring slightly as she handed him his change.

As the couple left, their laughter echoing behind them like a phantom taunt, Harriet allowed herself a moment of weakness. Leaning against the counter, she let the sadness wash over her, each wave more intense than the last. It was in this state that Mrs. Thompson's supervisor found her, concern etched on his face.

"Harriet," he said gently, "maybe it's time to take that break we've been talking about." But Harriet knew there was no break long enough to heal the wound in her heart, no vacation sufficient to ease the ache of loneliness. So she straightened up, wiped away her tears, and carried on with her duties, each step echoing with a profound, quiet sadness.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, another day, another dollar, another chance for things to fall apart. I swear, every time I put on my uniform, I feel like I'm putting on a mask. Like, what's the point of even trying? We're just going to get slammed today, and I'll be stuck here dealing with all these...people.

I saw that young couple come in earlier, and it just made me want to scream. They were so happy, so carefree. Meanwhile, I'm over here drowning in my own misery. I mean, who needs happiness when you've got bills to pay and a house to keep up?

And don't even get me started on the stuff they buy. Towels, kettles, throw rugs...it's all just a reminder of everything I've lost. My husband, my friends, my sense of purpose...all gone. And now I'm stuck here, alone, with nothing but my thoughts to keep me company.

I tried to put on a good face for that young guy, but honestly, I was struggling to breathe. He asked if I was okay, and I just nodded and handed him his change. What's the point of pretending? It's not like anything's going to change.

My supervisor came over and suggested I take a break, but I know it won't make a difference. Nothing ever does. I'll just end up sitting in some cramped office, staring at the wall, wondering where it all went wrong.

I guess that's just life, right? One disappointment after another. I'll just keep trudging along, waiting for the other shoe to drop. Because that's what always happens, isn't it?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
He stood there, chopping onions with fierce precision, tears streaming down his cheeks. Not from the damn alliums, though. It was fucking bullshit that she'd left him here, in this godforsaken kitchen, while she was off painting her little heart away at some retreat. "Artistic expression," my ass, he muttered, slamming a knife onto the counter.

He knew it wasn't about the cooking anymore. Not since they'd lost the baby. She blamed him for working late nights, for not being there when she needed him most. But fuck, he was here now, weren't he? Chopping and stirring like his life depended on it, trying to keep this goddamn restaurant afloat. And her... she was off chasing rainbows while their marriage was slowly burning down around them.

He paused, staring at the pile of neatly diced onions. It used to be their thing, cooking together. Now it just felt like another fucking chore. He took a deep breath, his chest heavy with sadness and anger. Then he grabbed the pan, pouring in more oil than necessary. Tonight, he'd cook like there was no tomorrow. And maybe, just maybe, she'd come home to find their marriage still on the menu.
Generated Assessment:
She's always been one to prioritize her art over our family. I swear, sometimes I think she forgets we're even having kids. The thought of her gallivanting off to some retreat, leaving me to deal with the mess of our lives, makes my blood boil. 

It's not like I'm the one who's been working non-stop to keep this place afloat. I'm the one who's been holding everything together while she's off chasing her dreams. And what does she do? She leaves me here, alone, to pick up the pieces. Like I'm some kind of servant, waiting to cater to her every whim.

And don't even get me started on the baby. If only she hadn't gotten pregnant, none of this would have happened. None of the stress, the tension, the constant fighting. We wouldn't be stuck in this rut, and I wouldn't be so resentful all the time.

But no, instead she gets to paint her pretty pictures and live her best life, while I'm stuck here, dealing with the consequences of her choices. It's just not fair.<|eot_id|>
